liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: DeSantis donors are gathering at the Four Seasons Miami in anticipation of the governor's formal announcement on Twitter, but they're not alone. A crowd of protesters have gathered outside the hotel, with some of their signs reading "Florida hates Ron DeSantis."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anti-DeSantis protesters gather in Miami

children.content: DeSantis donors are gathering at the Four Seasons Miami in anticipation of the governor's formal announcement on Twitter, but they're not alone.
A crowd of protesters have gathered outside the hotel, with some of their signs reading "Florida hates Ron DeSantis."

props.alt: Protesters gather as a woman speaks into a megaphone.

children.content: (AP Photo/Marta Lavandier)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ron DeSantis will announce he's entering the 2024 presidential race during a Twitter Spaces discussion with billionaire Elon Musk, the first time such an announcement will be made on social media. Spaces is a public feature on Twitter where users can have live audio conversations. Any user with 600 or more followers can host a Space, and up to 13 people can speak at any given time. It's an interesting choice considering the platform isn't easily accessible to everyone. New York Times reporter Nicholas Nehamas wrote: "One older donor told me he had no idea how to join a Twitter Space." The session will be moderated by tech entrepreneur and close Musk confidant David Sacks — according to NBC, he's a major Republican donor supporting DeSantis and is considered to be part of Musk's inner circle on decisions about Twitter. Earlier this week, Musk said he's "interested in Twitter being somewhat of a town square." During a conference hosted by the Wall Street Journal this week, Musk said he was not "at this time planning to endorse any particular candidate." But back in November Musk said he would support DeSantis in 2024 if the Florida governor were to run for president. "My preference for the 2024 presidency is someone sensible and centrist. I had hoped that would the case for the Biden administration, but have been disappointed so far," Musk had said on Twitter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What to know about Twitter Spaces

"One older donor told me he had no idea how to join a Twitter Space."
The session will be moderated by tech entrepreneur and close Musk confidant
David Sacks
— according to NBC, he's a major Republican donor supporting DeSantis and is considered to be part of Musk's inner circle on decisions about Twitter.

But back in

Musk said he would support DeSantis in 2024 if the Florida governor were to run for president.
"My preference for the 2024 presidency is someone sensible and centrist. I had hoped that would the case for the Biden administration, but have been disappointed so far," Musk had said on Twitter.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reports of "sextortion" to the eSafety Commissioner have tripled in the first quarter of 2023, with victims most likely to be young men. Sextortion involves criminals soliciting sexual images and videos from victims to use to blackmail them and extort money. Most of the incidents reported occurred on Snapchat and Instagram. Australia's eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant tells ABC News Breakfast that the typical victim is changing. "Image-based abuse, so the non-consensual sharing of intimate images and videos has always been gendered in terms of women and girls," she says. "But now what we're seeing is 90 per cent of the targets or the victims are young men between the ages of 18 and 24." Grant says that eSafety is able to help people that are being blackmailed as they have the power to take images down online. "We have a 90 per cent success rate in terms of doing that." You can keep reading about this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reports of 'sextortion' have tripled, says eSafety Commissioner

featuredLink.title: Instagram and Snapchat are the most-used platforms for 'sextortion', with young men most at risk

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's energy regulator says electricity prices will rise by up to 24 per cent from July 1, for around 600,000 customers in South Australia, New South Wales and South-East Queensland. The increase is higher than the draft offer put forward by the regulator in March, which suggested increases of between 20 and 22 per cent. You can read more on this breaking story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Electricity prices to rise for around 600,000 customers again in July

featuredLink.title: Electricity prices to rise by up to 24 per cent in New South Wales, South-East Queensland and South Australia

children.content: Australia's energy regulator says
electricity prices will rise by up to 24 per cent from July 1
, for around 600,000 customers in South Australia, New South Wales and South-East Queensland.
The increase is higher than the draft offer put forward by the regulator in March, which suggested increases of between 20 and 22 per cent.
You can read more on this breaking story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has officially entered the 2024 US presidential race. He's stepping into a crowded Republican primary contest which will test his national appeal as an outspoken cultural conservative and the GOP's willingness to move on from former president Donald Trump — who is also running for presidnet. The 44-year-old DeSantis revealed his decision in a Federal Election Commission filing before an online conversation with Twitter CEO Elon Musk, which is expected to take place around 8am AEST this morning. DeSantis is considered to be Trump's strongest Republican rival even as the governor faces questions about his readiness for the national stage.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ron DeSantis confirms he's running against Trump for US president

props.alt: Three men, one with white hair, sit next to each other at a table, wearing suits and ties

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Following hot on the heels of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand effectively calling an end to its aggressive rate hike cycle with one last increase yesterday, we got minutes from the latest US Federal Reserve meeting. The Fed seems very divided by those 'hawks' who believe rates need to keep going up until inflation falls back much closer to target and 'doves' who believe that the current level of rates will do that job, given some time. This from ANZ research's morning note, compiled by John Bromhead : "Fed officials were divided at the May meeting over whether further hikes would be needed. "Some were concerned that inflation was not falling fast enough, warranting further hikes, while others noted the full effects of past tightening are yet to be felt and tighter credit conditions from recent banking sector stresses could be equivalent to one or two hikes. "Officials stressed that future decisions will be dependent on the incoming data, supporting what has been said by Fed speakers in recent weeks. Markets are currently pricing in a 29% chance of a hike in June." Meanwhile, a report from the AFR's political correspondent Phillip Coorey (paywalled) suggests another Philip, Lowe, is not done with raising interest rates in Australia. Apparently, the RBA governor gave a very pessimistic private briefing to members of the House of Representatives economics committee, saying the odds of staying on the "narrow path" between avoiding recession and getting inflation down were not great. He also reportedly said that he doesn't have any tolerance for inflation remaining high for a long time and will do what he believes needs to be done to get it back down.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets still focused on interest rates amid news from Fed, RBNZ and RBA

children.content: Following hot on the heels of
the Reserve Bank of New Zealand effectively calling an end to its aggressive rate hike cycle with one last increase yesterday
, we got
minutes from the latest US Federal Reserve meeting

The Fed seems very divided by those 'hawks' who believe rates need to keep going up until inflation falls back much closer to target and 'doves' who believe that the current level of rates will do that job, given some time.
This from
ANZ research's morning note, compiled by John Bromhead
"Fed officials were divided at the May meeting over whether further hikes would be needed.

"Some were concerned that inflation was not falling fast enough, warranting further hikes, while others noted the full effects of past tightening are yet to be felt and tighter credit conditions from recent banking sector stresses could be equivalent to one or two hikes.

"Officials stressed that future decisions will be dependent on the incoming data, supporting what has been said by Fed speakers in recent weeks. Markets are currently pricing in a 29% chance of a hike in June."
Meanwhile,
a report from the AFR's political correspondent Phillip Coorey
(paywalled) suggests another Philip, Lowe, is not done with raising interest rates in Australia.
Apparently,
the RBA governor gave a very pessimistic private briefing to members of the House of Representatives economics committee
, saying the odds of staying on the "narrow path" between avoiding recession and getting inflation down were not great.
He also reportedly said that he doesn't have any tolerance for inflation remaining high for a long time and will do what he believes needs to be done to get it back down.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Markets have been very calm over the past few weeks, even as the US government hurtles towards a potential default as talks about raising the debt ceiling drag on. It's been a sense of, 'we've seen this movie before', with the US approaching default a few times over the past dozen years and a deal being struck at the last minute to avert catastrophe. But, while positive noises continue to emerge from Washington DC, traders are now getting a bit jittery that a deal still seems some way off from emerging. Overnight, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen confirmed that the latest estimates have the US running out of emergency measures to keep paying the bills by June 1, known as the X-date. The main markets on Wall Street fell between 0.6-0.8% overnight. European markets actually had much bigger falls, with the FTSE and Eurostoxx down 1.8%. The ASX will not be immune, with the futures down 0.4% at 7,196 points .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Debt ceiling countdown starting to spook traders on Wall Street

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: All the discussion around the default market offers is pretty complex and at times confusing, so we're here to answer your questions … if we can. Fire away, and also feel free to ask about what's happening on the markets or in economics. Just remember, we do not and cannot offer any kind of financial advice, just general information.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Got any questions about the default electricity price rises? We're here to help
